title: 111_hr2324
content: The Act titled "Gun Show Loophole Closing Act of 2009" aims to implement background checks at gun shows. The Congress finds that approximately 5,200 traditional gun shows are held annually in the US, attracting many attendees and firearms sellers. These shows provide easy access for criminals and prohibited persons to obtain firearms without background checks or traceable records. The legislation defines the sale, exchange, or transfer of firearms, excluding personal collections at private residences and events with fewer than 100 firearms offered by not-for-profit organizations. Gun show vendors, who are not licensed under section 923, exhibit, sell, or exchange firearms at gun shows. The legislation also regulates firearms transfers at gun shows by adding a new chapter to Title 44. The legislation regulates firearms transfers at gun shows by adding a new chapter to Title 44, requiring gun show operators to meet certain criteria to operate legally. The legislation requires gun show operators to register with the Attorney General, provide fingerprints and a photograph, certify compliance with certain requirements, and not willfully violate any provisions or make false statements. Gun show operators must notify the Attorney General before the show, provide vendor information, verify vendor identities, and pay a registration fee determined by the Attorney General. Before the gun show starts, the person who will be a vendor must verify their identity with a valid ID containing a photo, sign a ledger with identifying information, and sign a notice outlining vendor obligations. Before a gun show starts, vendors must verify their identity, sign a ledger, and acknowledge their obligations. The show organizer must provide a notice outlining vendor obligations and inform attendees of the requirements. Vendors must maintain records to demonstrate compliance and follow regulations set by the Attorney General. Additionally, background checks are required before firearm transfers between unlicensed persons. Background checks are required before transferring firearms between unlicensed persons at gun shows. Licensed individuals must record firearm details and notify both parties involved in the transfer. Licensed individuals must notify both the prospective transferor and transferee of a unique identification number from the national instant criminal background check system. They are also required to submit a report to the Attorney General within 10 days of the transfer, detailing the firearm's make, model, and serial number. The transfer of firearms requires a report to the Attorney General within 10 days, detailing the make, model, and serial number of the firearm. The report must be in a specified form and include necessary information, excluding personal details of unlicensed individuals involved in the transfer. Additionally, the licensee must retain a record of the transfer as part of their permanent business records. The Attorney General is prohibited from imposing recordkeeping requirements on gun show vendors under this section. The Attorney General is prohibited from imposing recordkeeping requirements on gun show vendors under this section. Penalties for knowingly violating specific subsections of section 932 include fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. Additionally, the Attorney General may impose additional penalties on those who violate any provision of section 932. The Attorney General may impose penalties, including suspension or revocation of registration and a fine of up to $10,000, on individuals who knowingly violate section 932. The Attorney General has the authority to inspect gun show operators' records and inventory to ensure compliance with firearm transfer regulations. Gun show operators and licensees conducting business at gun shows will not require a showing of reasonable cause or a warrant. Reports of multiple sales assisted by licensees at gun shows are subject to increased penalties for serious recordkeeping violations. Increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements include fines and imprisonment for up to 10 years for certain offenses under section 922 of the title. (g) Increased Penalties for Violations of Criminal Background Check Requirements include amending penalties under section 924(a)(5) of title 18, United States Code. This involves increasing penalties from 1 to 5 for violations of section 922(t) and eliminating certain elements of the offense. Additionally, (h) grants the Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives the authority to hire 40 additional Industry Operations Investigators for inspecting gun shows. The Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives is required to submit biennial reports to Congress on the sale of firearms at gun shows, background check procedures, resource needs, and recommendations for improvement. This section and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
